docs.lead_paragraph: The doctor's chicken scratch is barely legible, but to Luis Figueroa the scribbles on the little white slips of paper are precious. They are prescriptions for powerful new AIDS medications that once miraculously revived Mr. Figueroa, who was so close to death last year that his parents brought in a priest in case he needed last rites. But there is a problem with the prescriptions. Mr. Figueroa cannot afford to fill them, and the government cannot afford to fill them for him.

headline.main: AIDS Drugs Elude the Grasp of Many of the Poor

docs.abstract: Experts estimate that tens of thousands of people who could benefit from new state-of-the-art AIDS therapy are not receiving it, special report, Left Behind; say: drugs are expensive and many cannot afford them, many with HIV do not seek treatment, new protease inhibitor regimen is complex requiring up to 30 pills per day, and that some doctors are purposely withholding drugs, fearing that unstable patients will miss their doses and virus will become resistant; say as HIV continues to spread among poor, main obstacle is increasingly money; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Doubts on Cost Are Bedeviling Climate Policy'' (front page, Oct. 6) examines the costs of changing energy policies to address climate change, but the issue of avoiding the economic damages from climate disruption receives less mention. The insurance industry and public health community are not so sanguine.

headline.main: Climate Change Imposes Heavy Financial Cost

docs.abstract: Dr Paul R Epstein and Franklin Nutter letter comments on October 8 article on high cost of changing energy policies to address climate change (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: State Street Global Advisors, which runs the SSgA family of funds, is leading the way for large mutual fund companies into the new world of medical savings accounts. Medical savings accounts became available in January as a kind of medical I.R.A. They are intended for the self-employed and the employees of small companies and are packaged with high-deductible health insurance to cover serious illness. Contributions to the accounts are tax-deductible, and interest earned on the savings is tax-exempt, as long as all the money withdrawn from the account is used for medical expenses. At age 65, account holders can withdraw the money for any purpose without penalty.
docs.abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; State Street Global Advisors is leading way for large mutual fund companies into new world of medical savings accounts, offering investment options in 15 of its no-loan funds; Heartland Advisors is subsidizing all fees for its Heartland Large Cap Value fund and is reimbursing its Mid Cap Value fund so that its total annual expenses do not exceed 1.25 percent of assets in bid to draw new money (M)
docs.snippet: State Street Global Advisors, which runs the SSgA family of funds, is leading the way for large mutual fund companies into the new world of medical savings accounts.     Medical savings accounts became available in January as a kind of medical I.R.A....

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a glorious spring day in the Bavarian Alps, only a few snow-capped mountains over from where Julie Andrews sang, our party assembled for a six-hour ''health walk.'' The plan was to ascend the stunning Wimbach gorge and the valley above it, stopping along the way at Wimbachschloss, a hunting lodge built in 1784 for the last local prince. Officially designated a Testwanderweg, or fitness trail, this itinerary is among several developed for the tourist office in Berchtesgaden under the guidance of a specialist in rehabilitative sports therapy. Health-conscious hikers can assess their fitness by monitoring their heart rates at designated points on the trails. The tourist office sponsors health hikes five days a week in the warmer months. So seriously do Germans take the idea of ''walking cures'' that the cost of such excursions is generally covered by national health insurance. When I signed up for a hike, my fitness goal was modest: to keep pace with my fellow hikers -- Germans all -- and thus bring shame neither to my country nor to my personal trainer back at Crunch Fitness in Greenwich Village. Ha!
docs.abstract: Ann Banks article on visiting Berchtesgaden area of Germany's Bavarian Alps; describes organized 'health walk' on officially designated fitness trail; maps; photos (L)û

docs.lead_paragraph: For Cancer Research MONDAY -- Frederica von Stade, the mezzo-soprano, and Tyne Daly, the actress, will perform at a black-tie gala at the Pierre to benefit the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation. Marilyn Horne will be the master of ceremonies. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by the performance and dinner. Tickets, $750, from (212) 935-1840. New Year's Celebration TUESDAY -- A cocktail reception celebrating Rosh ha-Shanah will benefit the American Jewish Congress, New York Metropolitan Region. Tom Rogers, the president of NBC's cable division, will be honored. The 6 to 9 P.M. event, at the Rihga Royal Hotel, 151 West 54th Street, will help support the organization's anti-discrimination efforts. Tickets, $125, from (212) 360-1568.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey residents lead healthier lives than those in three-fourths of the nation, according to a survey released last week. New Jersey ranks 12th from the top when all of the factors considered by the Reliastar Financial Corporation of Minneapolis in its annual evaluation are combined. The survey considered such seemingly diverse factors as a state's unemployment rate because that has a bearing on a person's ability to obtain health insurance; the rates of heart disease, cancer and infectious diseases like AIDS; the mortality rate; job-related fatalities, and motor vehicle deaths.

headline.main: New Jersey, Healthy for All, Aiming at Health of the Elderly

docs.abstract: Reliastar Financial Corp releases survey showing that New Jerseyans are healthier than 75 percent of Americans; NJ Health and Senior Services Department is drafting regulations to offer elderly influenza and pneumonia vaccinations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An annual analysis of 16 social indicators shows the nation's social health is improving, but noted that this was only the second time in seven years that such an improvement has been seen. The analysis, the Index of Social Health, is produced by the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y. It is constructed on the model of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, combining statistics from a number of areas, from drug abuse to average wages.

headline.main: Report Says Health of Society Lags Behind That of Economy

docs.abstract: Index of Social Health, annual analysis of 16 social indicators, shows nation's social health is improving, but notes that this is only second time in seven years that such improvement has been seen; analysis is produced by Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is shopping season for high-school student travel overseas for next summer. These days, it is also shopping time for children as young as sixth grade. Catalogues and applications arrive and are perused. Notices appear on school bulletin boards. Meetings are held. Families call other families about their experiences. Parents have good reason to be concerned with good references. Unlike a summer camp, which you can visit, organizations that sponsor student travel may be just an amorphous 800 number. Adults may be unsure whom they are dealing with, even if a familiar teacher has signed on as a tour leader. Frequently, as families learn, a teacher is signing up after hearing from a colleague about a good experience a year, or even years, before.
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler article offers advice on groups sponsoring student travel abroad; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments. The move is a sharp departure from industry practice. Until now, most H.M.O.'s have been billed for each visit and procedure required in the treatment of everything from hip replacement surgery to heart bypass operations, plus additional amounts for diagnostic tests, hospital services and blood-laboratory reports, as well as follow-up care like physical therapy.

headline.main: H.M.O. Switches to Flat Fee For Treatment by Specialists

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans, one of country's biggest health maintenance organizations, has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments; move is sharp departure from industry practice; Oxford says it has contracted with over 700 specialists to take full charge of cases from start to finish; economists and health care experts say new approach is latest development in trend to give more authority to doctors and replace managed-care restraints that have enraged many doctors, frustrated patients and spurred lawmakers to scrutinize industry's billing practices (M)
docs.snippet: One of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments. The move is a sharp departure from industry...

docs.lead_paragraph: After cultivating a reputation as a conservative Republican who slashed welfare benefits, pushed for a broader death penalty and took on state employee unions, Gov. John G. Rowland today began an effort to highlight his softer side: he cares about children. More than a year before the gubernatorial election, Mr. Rowland has started to broadcast a television commercial that Democrats are calling the first ad of his campaign. In the 30-second spot, he is shown playing with Legos with youngsters in a nursery school setting and touting his plan to provide health insurance to 90,000 poor children.

headline.main: New TV Ad For Rowland Shows Voters His Soft Side

docs.abstract: Gov John G Rowland of Connecticut begins television ad campaign showing his soft and caring side even though he has not yet announced whether he will seek re-election in 1998; as governor he as has cultivated reputation as conservative Republican who slashed welfare benefits, pushed for broader death penalty and took on state employee unions (M)
